name: El Capitan From Yosemite Valley
description:
This strenuous hike is a real classic in Yosemite National Park. You start near famous Camp 4, from where you hike to the summit of El Capitan. The granite monolith, also known as "El Cap", is one of the most famous and impressive rock formations in the world.

For this hike into the Yosemite wilderness, you should not only be in decent shape but also bring sturdy shoes, a GPS device, sufficient provisions, and possibly a water filter and trekking poles. The first few miles are almost...

reviews.text:
Trail condition was excellent to the top of Yosemite Falls.  Did not see anybody from Yosemite Falls to El Capitan and the trail was largely slushy snow - trail was easy to follow.  Brought snow shoes - did not need them.  Did use micro spikes for some sections which was helpful.  9 hours of moving time, 10 hours total time with lunch at El Capitan. 

Started about 7:30am and finished at 5:25 - plenty of parking in the overflow for Camp 4.

With the government shutdown, there were no fees. 

A c
reviews.date:
{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/california/el-capitan-from-yosemite-valley","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"El Capitan from Yosemite Valley","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"Yosemite Valley, California, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Trail condition was excellent to the top of Yosemite Falls.  Did not see anybody from Yosemite Falls to El Capitan and the trail was largely slushy snow - trail was easy to follow.  Brought snow shoes - did not need them.  Did use micro spikes for some sections which was helpful.  9 hours of moving time, 10 hours total time with lunch at El Capitan. 

Started about 7:30am and finished at 5:25 - plenty of parking in the overflow for Camp 4.

With the government shutdown, there were no fees. 

A couple of observations:  

AllTrails mileage is not accurate for this hike.  Total mileage from the start/finish of the trail was closer to 16 miles and 4900’ elevation gain.  Our hike was 16.5 because we added a stop at Yosemite Falls. 
Also, to get to the edge of El Capitan it is a decent of +/- 650 ft and the climb back up to the peak after a lunch was something to rethink.  

The views from the edge of El Capitan were average, perhaps even a little disappointing (relative to Yosemite standards) - we did a side trip to Yosemite Falls this trip but did not do Eagle Point which many have said does have amazing views - have to do this next time. 

As others have mentioned, definitely a more advanced hike - the most difficult portion was the first 3.2 miles and the last 3.2 miles up and down from the Yosemite Falls trail.  Slushy snow makes you work a little harder but a really good day.  


 ","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Greg Mellor","url":"/members/greg-mellor-1"}}

reviews.text: Good challenge! The initial 3 mile ascent to the upper falls was tough, but a good workout. We started by 7:45am and the trail was not crowded and there was plenty of parking across from camp 4. It took us 1hr 45min to get to the top of the falls, lots of sun exposure in the morning so bring plenty of water 3-4L total for the in/out. We took the eagle point detour on the way to El Capitan, definitely a must, the view was amazing and a great snack spot. The 0.3 miles (more like 0.4-0.5) to get th

What an amazing experience. Getting up to Upper Yosemite falls was no joke and was the hardest part, the majority of the rest of the trail consists of rolling hills and some granite walking. We did detour to Eagle Peak on our way to the El Cap summit and I can’t recommend that enough, those the greatest views I’ve ever seen. Give yourself plenty of time to come down from Upper Yosemite falls, it was just as difficult as going up. My only complaint is the amount of fallen logs on the trail that y
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/california/el-capitan-from-yosemite-valley","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"El Capitan from Yosemite Valley","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"Yosemite Valley, California, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"What an amazing experience. Getting up to Upper Yosemite falls was no joke and was the hardest part, the majority of the rest of the trail consists of rolling hills and some granite walking. We did detour to Eagle Peak on our way to the El Cap summit and I can’t recommend that enough, those the greatest views I’ve ever seen. Give yourself plenty of time to come down from Upper Yosemite falls, it was just as difficult as going up. My only complaint is the amount of fallen logs on the trail that you have to climb over. 10/10 would do it again.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Cristina Marandici","url":"/members/cristina-marandici"}}

reviews.text: 02/07 Lots of downed trees near the last 2 miles. Lots of hard packed ice and snow once you clear the stairs. You will be hiking through snow for a solid 3 miles. Still a great hike. Bring lots of water and food! It’s going to be a long one.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/california/el-capitan-from-yosemite-valley","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"El Capitan from Yosemite Valley","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"Yosemite Valley, California, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":4},"reviewBody":"02/07 Lots of downed trees near the last 2 miles. It’s going to be a long one.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Anson Wong","url":"/members/anson-wong-42"}}

reviews.text: Backpacked the trail and camped on top of half dome. V

name: Tamarack Flat To El Capitan
description: This is a challenging, but extremely rewarding trail. The first 2.5 miles is fairly simple downhill on a semi paved forest road to a small footbridge over Tamarack Creek. After that, is about 6 miles of steady and sometimes aggressive elevation gain. There are not a ton of switchbacks, but more direct uphill sections, followed by longer exposed sections of granite crossings. There is a nice interlude in a meadow / sparse forested area before continuing uphill to the opening to the...

reviews.text: Very tough hike but the view from El Captain is all worth it!
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/california/tamarack-flat-to-el-capitan","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Tamarack Flat to El Capitan","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"El Portal, California, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Very tough hike but the view from El Captain is all worth it!","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"M M","url":"/members/m-m-2391"}}

reviews.text: Trail is super clear and not crowded during summer due to the dryness. Hard to find parking.

Pros:
The vegetation is lush, and the scenery opens up beautifully toward the end.

Cons:
There are two stretches of trail that feel like mosquito forests — dozens of wild mosquitoes swarming and hard to shake off.

Features:
In the forest, there were repeated sounds of branches snapping, which felt a bit creepy.

Day 2: Wow, just soo good. Bit of a climb in the middle of the day but the views… just so worth it. Great view on El Capitan, middle Cathedral, falling tower, a waterfall and of course Half Dome. Crazy

We started our hike from the **Tamarack Creek trailhead**. This review is primarily to provide information about water sources, as I found very little information online while researching. There was minimal information about where you can refill your water bottles with filters. We began this hike with the intention of reaching **El Capitan**, but only if we could refill water along the way, as carrying too much water in our backpacks was not ideal.

We started our hike on **Friday, August 23**,

name: Old Big Oak Flat To Yosemite Falls
description: This trail begins at the Old Big Oak Flat trailhead and is a gradual climb to Cascade Creek. There are multiple water sources on the first stretch. After passing the footbridge, it is a moderately steep uphill climb to the summit of El Capitan. Going downhill after El Capitan, there is an optional summit of Eagle Peak before meeting the trail junction of Upper Yosemite Falls. Last stretch is a steep and rocky downhill decent on Upper Yosemite Falls trail ending at the trailhead / Camp...

reviews.text: Mostly dry streams. Most of the named creeks still have flowing water although some are just stagnant puddles. Bring filter & tabs. Also bring a head bug net otherwise you’ll be inhaling gnats.

Challenging trail, but so beautiful and with different landscapes. We did in 3 nights so we could enjoy more. First night we spend close to ribbon creek. Second night at eagle peak and third night at Yosemite creek. Till now the trail has plenty of water. Mosquitoes can be really annoying and we had a mosquito net which was very handy in some parts, specially close to the meadows.
We left the car parked at the trailhead and to go back we hitchhiked from camp 4.

6/7/25 - 6/8/25. Did this trail as a one night backpacking trip, camping near the top of Eagle Peak. Great views, especially after passing El Cap. The first half isn’t too scenic, though there are a lot of wildflowers. 

The best views on the trail were at Eagle Peak though, so definitely don’t miss it. If you want to camp there, there is one small spot at the top, and a couple that are down a little ways. However, finding a good area can be pretty tricky - not many flat areas and many spots hav
reviews.date:
{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/california/old-big-oak-flat-to-yosemite-falls","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Old Big Oak Flat to Yosemite Falls","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"Yosemite Valley, California, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"6/7/25 - 6/8/25. Did this trail as a one night backpacking trip, camping near the top of Eagle Peak. Great views, especially after passing El Cap. The first half isn’t too scenic, though there are a lot of wildflowers. 

The best views on the trail were at Eagle Peak though, so definitely don’t miss it. If you want to camp there, there is one small spot at the top, and a couple that are down a little ways. However, finding a good area can be pretty tricky - not many flat areas and many spots have ant hills. It’s definitely worth the hassle, as you can get a really good sunset and sunrise. If you don’t camp here, the next best spot is probably after the Eagle Peak turnout in the direction of Upper Falls.

Tons of water sources along the way, though good portion of them will be dry later this year. The best is Cascade Creek - tons of swimming spots and many pools where you can catch trout if you want to fish.

Upper Falls is still flowing strong right now, but will most likely be much slower in about a month. I think the best views weren’t at the very top, but at some of the viewpoints on the way down.

For parking, we left one car at Big Oak Flat and another at Yosemite Village. It’ll add a little bit extra at the end to get to Yosemite Village, but the wilderness station said you cannot park at the Upper Falls lot overnight.

Another note - if you’re into birds, I heard a Northern Pygmy Owl at Eagle Peak early in the morning. The call was very clear and it went on for a long time. If I had more time, I would’ve tried finding it.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Kendall E","url":"/members/kendall-outside"}}

reviews.text: Lots of snow from mile ~4 through mile 12. Put the boot pack in tho.

Solid trail. Just completed yesterday 9/29/24. Did the whole trail in 7 hours flat. Very mellow with some steep parts going towards el cap. If you want the edge picture like I got you gotta walk down the pinnacle and it’s super steep getting back up lol. Then headed back down Yosemite falls which was cool. Those endless switch backs are true to their name.

If you want the edge picture like I got you gotta walk down the pinnacle and it’s super steep getting back up lol. Then headed back down Yosemite falls which was cool. Those endless switch backs are true to their name. ","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Jacob Crist","url":"/members/jacob-crist-2"}}

name: El Capitan Loop
description:
Parking for this trailhead is across the street from Camp 4. Keep in mind that there is no day-use parking in the Camp 4 parking lot.

This trail begins by ascending the steep and popular Yosemite Falls trail. Be prepared to encounter crowds on this part of the trail. As soon as you hit the split to Eagle Peal/El Capitan the crowds disappear. Continue on to the summits of Eagle Peak and El Capitan. Loop back down to the valley via Old Big Oak Flat Road and Rockslides Trail. Rockslides Trail...

reviews.text: Rockslide trail is basically not a trail anymore. Mostly scrambles and you cant tell if you are actually on a trail or not until halfway through. I would NOT recommend.

The portion of the trail descending from El Captain to the valley floor is completely unmaintained! I was literally crawling on my hands and knees over and under 100s of downed trees and many rock slides, also lost the trail several times and had to use the map to refind it. Seems like they abandoned the trail maybe 10 years ago.

First part was great though
Expect most of the loop back to be at your own risk.

JUST DO THE OUT AND BACK, SKIP THE LOOP.
We took this on as a single day hike counterclockwise starting from Upper Yosemite Falls Trail. As with any long distance hikes trail conditions are important in the planning. There really should be a revised route for this loop. The first half is great, especially the view from Eagle Peak. Excellent! After that it goes downhill. The hike over to El Capitan is okay, standing on El Cap is just okay, there’s no view of the wall at any point but the view of
reviews.date:
{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/california/el-capitan-loop","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"El Capitan Loop","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"Yosemite Valley, California, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":2},"reviewBody":"JUST DO THE OUT AND BACK, SKIP THE LOOP.
We took this on as a single day hike counterclockwise starting from Upper Yosemite Falls Trail. As with any long distance hikes trail conditions are important in the planning. There really should be a revised route for this loop. The first half is great, especially the view from Eagle Peak. Excellent! After that it goes downhill. The hike over to El Capitan is okay, standing on El Cap is just okay, there’s no view of the wall at any point but the view of the valley is pretty good. I’d suggest an out and back from that point. 

The hike down to Old Big Oak Flat Rd is fine but once you start that Old Big Oak Flat Rd stretch its absolute trash. I’m an experienced athletic hiker and my patience was really tested. The trail was probably good 30yrs ago. It’s littered with big downed trees throughout and the last 1/3 has two large bolder washout fields. We were fed up with it and decided to scramble down one of the dangerous stone avalanche fields then had to bushwhack to Northside Drive for a flat long slog back to the valley. Though we had headlamps daylight was running short as well as water.  

The last 10 miles really sucked and only offered views of El Cap at the very end. NOT WORTH IT. I’d suggest a revised exit route after El Capitan Trail with a shuttle car parked. You’ll appreciate the time back to go do something else. ","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Dave Noel","url":"/members/dave-noel-11"}}

reviews.text: The second half of the trail made it a bad and even dangerous experience. We went counter-clockwise, and the second half of the trail, starting from the juncture at old big oak flat, is actually not passible. It is full of fallen big trees at the beginning, which significantly slowed down our speed. Then acta while we encountered more and more stone and finally a stone slide which went all the way to the bottom near the road. The wide stone slide totally blocked the nearly nonexistent “trail”. W

name: El Capitan Via Old Big Oak Flat
description:
From Big Oak Flat Rd a short exposed ascent leveling out briefly before heading downhill.  Hillsides are covered with wildflowers and manzanita. Multiple water crossings, best attempted after mid August. Rest of the trail is mostly shaded although a long ascent is pretty exposed after crossing the bridge. Views are really amazing from the top. 

--

This is one of Yosemite's many backpacking routes. While some can be done as a day hike, a permit is required if you plan on doing a multi-day...

reviews.text:
Did this as an epic day hike but could be a cool backpacking trip. About 8.5 hours from 9am-5:30pm at a good pace and with no real breaks except at the top. If you want to see the edge of the wall, it’s quite a bit past the map and steep so add time for that. Not much for views but once you get to the top it’s incredible.

No snow Nov 6. Incline is mostly gradual but there are a few slogs. Most of the trail is clear but I did get lost a few times so download a map and have fun!

super tough on the way up- took us about 8 hours but we stopped a lot to rest! amazing views and perfect camping on el cap. got down in about 4 hours. good water sources and mostly shaded which is nice

We did this trail with our two kids who are 9 and 11….but that does not mean it’s an easy trail. Our kids have been hiking since birth. Parts of the trail were step and there was at least one good water crossing. That being said make sure you fill up at ribbon creek because once you pass that there’s no water. Ribbon creek also had a ton of mosquitoes. We camped on top of El Cap, with amazing stars, a herd of deer, and views of half dome. This is a hike we will never forget and if you can do it
LOTS of snow. LOTS OF SNOW. Bring snow shoes. Be prepared for a 13 hour day. Still an amazing hike though. We had a great time though. Just be prepared to send it and get some wet feet
Great long walk!! View of Half Dome and valley from El Cap was well worth it!!

name: Full North Rim
description: The Full North Rim Trail travels up out of Yosemite Valley and along the northern rim of Yosemite Valley, visiting El Capitan, Eagle Peak, Yosemite Falls, Yosemite Point, North Dome and Basket Dome. Either Old Big Oak Flat Road or Snow Creek trailhead can be used. During the late summer months, be sure to check water flow levels as they can be low or non-existent and you may need to carry all your water with you. The route is generally completed in 2-3 days and there is a shuttle service that...

reviews.text:
Did this hike in June over 3 great days of weather. Truly amazing! 

Best camping spots for views are Eagle Peak (great views of the valley east and west) and North Dome (you get to stare at Half Dome and a short hike to the end of Half Dome gives great views to the west). Better than El Capitan and other options.
Incredible trail. Lots of uncleared, fallen trees, a little bit of snow, many stream crossings, but very doable

Completed as a backpacking trip in three days, on May 2-4. Some tricky stream crossings, and LOTS of water in the meadow areas. The meadows on the northern side of Eagle Peak are particularly swampy and you have to get creative finding your way through. Behind North Dome is still very snowy, but in general this entire trail is now doable without spikes or snow shoes.

Completed SOLO 11/3/24 - West to East - Big Oak Road to Curry Village - 3 Days, 32 Miles

CHECK OUT MY FULL YOUTUBE VIDEOS at https://youtube.com/@dklivefit.

Before I scare you, let me say the trip was amazing! I am definitely glad I did it. The views were incredible. I only saw people (day hikers) on the section between El Capitan and Yosemite Falls. Other than that I had the trail, El Cap, Eagle Peak, North Dome, Indian Arch/Rock all to myself. The views from Indian Arch/Rock are awesome and
reviews.date:
{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/california/full-north-rim","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Full North Rim","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"Yosemite Valley, California, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Completed SOLO 11/3/24 - West to East - Big Oak Road to Curry Village - 3 Days, 32 Miles

CHECK OUT MY FULL YOUTUBE VIDEOS at https://youtube.com/@dklivefit.

Before I scare you, let me say the trip was amazing! I am definitely glad I did it. The views were incredible. I only saw people (day hikers) on the section between El Capitan and Yosemite Falls. Other than that I had the trail, El Cap, Eagle Peak, North Dome, Indian Arch/Rock all to myself. The views from Indian Arch/Rock are awesome and SUPER RARE as they are too isolated for day hikers. I was crossing untouched snow on the trail from two days prior.

This was an incredible adventure. I carried a 45 pound pack. The climb to elevation was brutal (4mi-7mi). The decent back into the valley is 2,600ft of switchbacks (26mi-28mi)... Ouch! It was some suffering on the last stretch to finish. This trail is not for the light hearted. YOU WILL BE CHALLENGED!

WARNING - If you are doing this trail late-season, make sure you are carrying plenty of water, you are monitoring the weather constantly, and you are prepared for rapid weather shifts. I was in shorts and T-shirt on the sunny trails and a ZERO degree sleeping bag at night.

SNOW - I caught a snow storm overnight on El Capitan and woke up to 2 inches of fresh snow. Most of it melted off as the sun came up and there was only snow on the trail through some of the shaded forest sections.

FOG & SUB-FREEZING TEMPS  - After a late start packing up post snow at El Capitan, I got to North Dome post sundet and super dense white out fog rolled in. I had to finish the last 1 mile looking at the GPS map on my phone because I could barely see the end of my trekking pole. I found camp in a wooded section by looking at the satellite images on the map. I was able to set up camp in the dark and made it through the 27degF COLD TEMP  night. KNARLY Experience!!! But I woke up straight across from Half Dome and view was majestic! 

BEAR - At Snow Creek, I came to a mama bear and her 2-3 cubs standing 25 yards in front of me on the trail. She stared at me for a moment then walked awake. 2 hours later, when I got down to the valley floor near Mirror Lake a couple told me they just saw a bear on the path in front of them.

CAMP:
Mile 10 - El Capitan
Mile 20 - North Dome

I backpacked the trail solo the first weekend in November which means water was a rare find. There were a few running streams heading up to Cascade Creek, then is was pretty much dry from Cascade to Yosemite Creek (12mi). There was water at Lehamite and Snow Creek, but I had cooler temps which meant plenty of water  to make it back to the valley.

WATER:
Start - Big Oak (3L)
Mile 4 - Cascade Creek (Had  3.5L, Filled to 4L)
Mile 16 - Yosemite Creek (Had 0.5L, Filled to 4L)
Mile 18.5 - Lehamite Creek (Skipped)
Mile 27 - Snow Creek (Skipped)
Finish - Had 1.0 L

Current Trail Conditions & Updates:
https://www.nps.gov/yose/planyourvisit/wildcond.htm

I this hope it helps!","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Darnell Kemp","url":"/members/darnell-kemp"}}

name: El Capitan From Tamarack Creek
description:
This route begins from Tioga Road at the Tamarack Creek Trailhead. You will travel through dense forests and over small creeks to reach the summit of El Capitan. Once at the summit, there are expansive views of Yosemite Valley below and Yosemite's high country.

--

This is one of Yosemite's many backpacking routes. While some can be done as a day hike, a permit is required if you plan on doing a multi-day trip. Permits are able to be reserved up to 24 weeks in advance and up until 4 days...

reviews.text:
As of June 20th/21rst 2025 the trail is well maintained, easy to follow for the most part. A few creeks crossings but feet stayed wet. Some logs to climb over or go around doable. Mosquitoes are hungry in the forested areas!! Cascade and ribbon creek are flowing and great to refill water.
The view from El Capitan at sundown and sunrise makes that biiiig climb all worth it. Slept on the eastern flanc of the summit, facing Half dome, camp site pictured.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/california/el-capitan-from-tamarack-creek","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"El Capitan from Tamarack Creek","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"Yosemite Valley, California, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"As of June 20th/21rst 2025 the trail is well maintained, easy to follow for the most part. A few creeks crossings but feet stayed wet. Some logs to climb over or go around doable. Mosquitoes are hungry in the forested areas!! Cascade and ribbon creek are flowing and great to refill water.\nThe view from El Capitan at sundown and sunrise makes that biiiig climb all worth it. Slept on the eastern flanc of the summit, facing Half dome, camp site pictured.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Victoria Durban","url":"/members/victoria-durban"}}

reviews.text:
Solo backpacking trip. Had to start from the Tioga Rd small parking lot because the road to Tamarack Flat Campground was close. However, the meadow view before the campground is awesome and flat. 

After passing the campground, the Old Big Oak Flat Rd Trail has many fallen trees. This section seems lack of maintenance recently. 

Cascade Creek is the last resort to refill water before the Ribbon Creek (2.5 km from El Cap), so don’t miss that. Check my other waypoints for water refill information

Did a 2 day/1 night backpacking trip along this route, camping about a mile past El Cap up on a high ridge with views. Mosquitoes and biting flies are out and very hungry!  Tamarack Creek trail is overgrown and buggy, but all the wildflowers are blooming right now. Bathrooms at CG were unlocked even though it’s closed. Most downed trees are along the old road between the CG and the bridge. The blooming azaleas smell absolutely amazing right now! Fill up on water and wet your shirt and hat in Cas
make sure to fill up at the bridge, the ascend after that is tough and has no water access until the top.

Hiked this as a 3 day 2 night trip. First day was from the road to the junction before heading uphill to El Cap, about 5.5 miles. Then on day 2 left our tents and gear at camp and did the out and back to the top of El Cap and back. This ended up being about 12 miles total. Then one the third day hiked out the 5.5 miles back to the road. Overall the trail was ok, overgrown from the road to Tamarack CG, then your on the old toll road until the climb starts. The climb is tough as it goes up quickly

name: Tamarack Flat To Yosemite Valley
description:
This trail begins at Tamarack Flat Campground and takes you to many notable high points along the north rim of Yosemite Valley - El Capitan, Eagle Peak, and the top of Yosemite Falls.

--

This is one of Yosemite's many backpacking routes. While some can be done as a day hike, a permit is required if you plan on doing a multi-day trip. Permits are able to be reserved up to 24 weeks in advance and up until 4 days beforehand. Permits and more information can be found here:...

reviews.text: We modified the hike and started at Porcupine Creek TH off Tioga Pass and hike towards North Dome on day 1. Great weather and crowds not too bad (saw few people on most of day 3). Views were spectacular from North Dome, Yosemite Falls area, and Eagle Peak. Camped at Lehamite creek the first night and Ribbon creek the second night.

Be sure to bring bug spray in the summer months. Lots of downed trees on the trail, but mostly well maintained. Only a few creeks with enough water for purification, but well spaced enough to camp by water every night.

Very challenging incline a few miles in, beautiful view from eagles peak (don’t skip it!!), but the ending was absolutely brutal. Expecting 3 miles of a downhill and instead getting 3 full miles of slick and extremely steep stone stairs that required hopping/crawling down for me at 5’6 , ended up causing sublingual hematomas in my feet that were excruciating, I’ve since lost one big toenail and have a stress fracture in my other foot. This ending stretch was unnecessarily brutal, had no real ups

Everything about this was worth more than five stars with the exception of the last 3.5 miles. The upper falls portion is legitimately miserable—miles of  crowded toe-breakingly steep and stoney switch backs with a view that only gets worse as you go forward. Everything else is challenging but rewarding and stunningly beautiful.

We completed this hike in August 2023. We used the hiker bus (from curry village at 8am) to drop us on Tioga Pass road and walked down the road to Tamarack Flat campground. We staged our car at the car park at the bottom of Yosemite falls. The trail had alot of downed trees along the way to El Cap. No problem with water on the hike to El Cap. We camped at El Cap and had some amazing views for sunset. We didnt have a water source on El Cap. Nearest one was a trickle about 0.3 miles before El Cap
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/california/tamarack-flat-to-yosemite-valley","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Tamarack Flat to Yosemite Valley","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"Yosemite Valley, California, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":4},"reviewBody":"We completed this hike in August 2023. We used the hiker bus (from curry village at 8am) to drop us on Tioga Pass road and walked down the road to Tamarack Flat campground. We staged our car at the car park at the bottom of Yosemite falls. The trail had alot of downed trees along the way to El Cap. No problem with water on the hike to El Cap. We camped at El Cap and had some amazing views for sunset. We didnt have a water source on El Cap. Nearest one was a trickle about 0.3 miles before El Cap that we had to carry up to the peak. \n\nThe hike from El Cap the next morning to yosemite falls was great, we started around 7am. Saw one bear on the way that took no interest in us. Once you get to Yosemite falls its a long hot hike down with lots of people on the trail. Rewarding hike!","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Jenn E","url":"/members/jennifer-ebbs-1"}}

name: Yosemite Creek Trail To Eagle Peak And El Capitan
description:
Yosemite Creek Trail to Eagle Peak, then Eagle Peak to El Capitan. Yosemite Creek trail to Yosemite Creek campground can be hard to follow, so downloading offline maps is highly recommended. The rest of the trail is nice and follows the creek most the way with partial sun and shade. Views from Eagle Peak are amazing!

--

This is one of Yosemite's many backpacking routes. While some can be done as a day hike, a permit is required if you plan on doing a multi-day trip. Permits are able to be...

reviews.text:
Wow just finished this challenging but amazing backpacking trip. 4 days 3 nights. My garmin gps watch clocked in at 27 miles all in all trails, scenic views, bathroom breaks, water, lunch breaks, etc. For beginning of July there was a reasonable amount of water for filtering: loads alongside yosemite creek to the falls, 3 between falls and eagle peak and 3 between eagle peak and  capitan. Lots of trees fallen down but the trails to walk around them are visible.
Trekking poles I would say are nec

Yosemite Creek trail to Eagle Peak, Eagle Peak to El Capitan. Yosemite Creek trail to Yosemite Creek campground is poorly maintained and hard to follow. The rest of the trail is nice, follows the creek most the way, partial sun and shade. Views from Eagle Peak are amazing! Did as a 3 night backpacking trip, 2 nights at Eagle peak, day hike to El Cap then a night along the river.

name: Tamarack Flat To Yosemite Creek
description:
This trail takes you to three incredible viewpoints along the north rim of Yosemite Valley - El Capitan, Eagle Peak, and the top of Yosemite Falls. The trail ends at Tioga Road.

--

This is one of Yosemite's many backpacking routes. While some can be done as a day hike, a permit is required if you plan on doing a multi-day trip. Permits are able to be reserved up to 24 weeks in advance and up until 4 days beforehand. Permits and more information can be found here:...

reviews.text: Trail had a grueling climb for a few miles and will be challenging for those not conditioned.  Water was challenging to find for about a 12 mile stretch of the trail in mid August, so be conservative and take 4 liters or more. The views above El Cap, Eagle Peak & Yosemite Falls made the trail well worth the work. There's a great camping spot about 6 miles from the Yosemite Creek trailhead.

name: Half Dome Via The John Muir Trail Jmt
description:
Half Dome is a serious endurance hike taking you 4,800 feet above the Yosemite Valley to spectacular views of Vernal and Nevada Falls, Liberty Cap, the Yosemite Valley, and the High Sierra. This is one of Yosemite National Park’s most iconic hikes. You must obtain a permit to hike to the summit of Half Dome. 

Preparation and safety are key to having a fantastic experience. This hike requires you to be in good shape. Most people take 10 to 12 hours to hike to Half Dome and back, depending on...

reviews.text: Backpacked to Little Yosemite Valley on Monday 1/26, climbed half dome the next day. Snow free conditions until LYV, where it gradually increased from an inch to over 18 inches at the sub-dome. From the base of sub dome and onwards micro spikes are a must, and trekking poles are strongly encouraged. A slide would be difficult to stop without them. Tracks made route finding easy. Small patches of hard ice and snow on the cable section. Overall very fun hike.
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/california/half-dome-via-the-john-muir-trail-jmt","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Half Dome via the John Muir Trail (JMT)","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"Yosemite Valley, California, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Backpacked to Little Yosemite Valley on Monday 1/26, climbed half dome the next day. Snow free conditions until LYV, where it gradually increased from an inch to over 18 inches at the sub-dome. From the base of sub dome and onwards micro spikes are a must, and trekking poles are strongly encouraged. A slide would be difficult to stop without them. Tracks made route finding easy. Small patches of hard ice and snow on the cable section. Overall very fun hike.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Micah Hikes","url":"/members/micah-gibson"}}

reviews.text: Misty trail detour was fixed and operational, after misty trail it gets kinda icy so take your time (This is misty trail end to liberty falls) from there the John Muir trail started off fine with it mainly getting hard the final mile or so before half dome with snow being roughly thigh height. Sub dome was completely snowed out with several mini paths being present but there where several moments where I stepped and feel into the snow even thought it was trekked on. Half dome was able to be comp

Cables are down, no ice on top, over 100 people that do not know what they are doing trying to tie off with rope to go up. This cause a major traffic jam and I sat on the side of half dome for 30 minutes just waiting holding onto the cable. Wish they would try to start on something smaller and practice first or just stay home. Overall most difficult hike I’ve done with elevation. Might be a one and done deal
Feb 8th conditions were perfect no snow or ice on cables definitely clip in to safe I also used a prusik knot just to be extra safe
Climbing half dome without a harness is sketchy asf in the winter but doable

name: Half Dome Via Little Yosemite Valley Campsite  2
description:
This is a day hike to the summit of Half Dome from Little Yosemite Valley. Many opt to stay the night in Little Yosemite Valley and day hike to Half Dome, so the hike is shorter and you won't have to carry a heavy pack.

Half Dome is a serious endurance hike taking you 4,800 feet above the Yosemite Valley to spectacular views of Vernal and Nevada Falls, Liberty Cap, the Yosemite Valley, and the High Sierra. This is one of Yosemite National Park’s most iconic hikes. You must obtain a permit to...

reviews.text: Hiked up to half dome on 10/20. The cables were still up but coming back down to the valley on 10/21 we met a ranger and he said 10/21 was probably going to be the last day they were up. He was also checking permits. Hike up was the steepest at the subdome and cables. Subdome is a lot of switch backs with exposed edges. Cables were tiring but totally doable. Definitely recommend a harness and clips for safety. It’s steeper than it looks in pictures! Was also not too crowded. More people as we ca
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/california/half-dome-via-little-yosemite-valley-campsite--2","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Half Dome via Little Yosemite Valley","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"Yosemite Valley, California, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"Hiked up to half dome on 10/20. The cables were still up but coming back down to the valley on 10/21 we met a ranger and he said 10/21 was probably going to be the last day they were up. He was also checking permits. Hike up was the steepest at the subdome and cables. Subdome is a lot of switch backs with exposed edges. Cables were tiring but totally doable. Definitely recommend a harness and clips for safety. It’s steeper than it looks in pictures! Was also not too crowded. More people as we came down but going up the cables there was only 2 other people.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Amanda Emery","url":"/members/amanda-emery-6"}}

reviews.text: I highly recommend grippy gloves and a via ferrata harness system for the cables to enjoy this epic climb. Clipping off and on around each stanchion only took about 6 seconds. We experienced consistent winds of about 30 mph with gusts that felt twice as strong on 10/9/25. Pebbles wrecked my sunglasses and my son lost his to the seemingly hurricane winds. We backpacked from Glacier Point to Little Yosemite Valley along the Panorama trail and got an early start in this trail early the next morning
reviews.date: {"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/california/half-dome-via-little-yosemite-valley-campsite--2","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Half Dome via Little Yosemite Valley","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"Yosemite Valley, California, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"I highly recommend grippy gloves and a via ferrata harness system for the cables to enjoy this epic climb. Clipping off and on around each stanchion only took about 6 seconds. We experienced consistent winds of about 30 mph with gusts that felt twice as strong on 10/9/25. Pebbles wrecked my sunglasses and my son lost his to the seemingly hurricane winds. We backpacked from Glacier Point to Little Yosemite Valley along the Panorama trail and got an early start in this trail early the next morning. A family of deer, including a doe nursing, greeted us on the journey back down. Wading in the Merced River provided a refreshing reward back at camp in LYV. ","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Toni M","url":"/members/toni-nunes"}}

reviews.text: Imagine preparing for 8 full months hiking almost all strenuous trails in the national park, hoping you’d be ready and then when you face the cables, your legs shiver, every muscle in your body is scared to go any further and yet you do it; only to realize going up the cables is the easiest part of the hike- that’s HALF DOME for you! I started my wilderness journey from Glacier Point, took the panorama trail, got to little Yosemite valley and camped the night. Started hiking up the trail at the

name: Diving Board
description:
This is a strenuous hike that requires off-trail navigation and scrambling. The Diving Board is not for those who are afraid of heights, as there is a 3,000ft drop to the valley floor below. Rock climbing and mountaineering skill are necessary to attempt this route.

This route takes you to the Diving Board, which is a steep granite slab beneath Half Dome. This is also the approach trail for many rock climbers.

reviews.text:
A tough hike with huge payoff. Avoid the turn north on the climber's route if you are looking to avoid exposure. On the out, I followed the technical route to the spot with exposed slabs - maybe 30 ft across with a fast 30-50 ft slide as the risk. Took a couple of steps out in 2 spots before deciding to down climb off the slabs and thrash through the bush and trees.

Pretty easy to find on the way back. However a ton of down trees makes it slow and hard to follow in spots.

This is my second completion of the Diving Board via Snake Dike Approach.  Did it one year ago on October 7th and was incredibly sketched out by the traverse along snake dike.

Was much more mentally prepared for the class 3 hiking section this time and managed to stay on trail through the later portion of snake dike.

Also descended the snake dike approach for the first time even though it was sprinkling so had to be extra careful on the exposure.

Is an incredibly fun and enjoyable hike with t

The trail is tricky to navigate, there are cairns, but be sure you download a map they can be spread out in sections.  The last mile up is HARD!  If you actually climb onto the Diving Board itself, my best advice is to travel through the gully that sends you straight up toward Half Dome, its through brush and scree to the side closest to Half Dome much safer approach from there.  The granite that comprises the slab that is the actual DB is severely steep.  I made the big mistake of going too hig

I think the hardest part of this trail is the navigation. I didn’t think the exposure or the scrambling was that bad if you stay on the AllTrails route. A few spots where a fall would be very bad, but otherwise a great adventure!
Never ever do this please. I’m on my way down now and I feel like I’m gonna die its vertical rock climbing face. Had to turn around early.

name: Cathedral Peak Climbers Approach
description: This trail takes you on the climber's approach trail to the base of Cathedral Peak. If you are looking for a challenge, continue along up the climber's descent route to the summit of Cathedral Peak. There are gorgeous views from the summit. The majority of the trail is a steady but not-too-steep uphill until near the top of the peak. At that point some scrambling and climbing are necessary to reach the summit where the view is the best.

reviews.text: Dangerous coming down .
Nice mellow grade until the last half mile where most of the elevation gain happens.
Sketch af!! NOT for the faint of heart. Or for the average climber to descend. Hated it.
The last quarter mile requires route finding chops, class 3 scrambling acumen and comfort with exposure.

name: Higher Cathedral Spire
description: This is an extremely steep approach to the base of Higher Cathedral Spire, a popular climbing destination. The trail is forested, but opens up to beautiful views of Higher Cathedral Spire and other notable Yosemite Landmarks towards the top. Downloading offline maps is recommended to help you navigate this challenging trail.

reviews.text:
Fun little hike, very steep and the trail is a little tough to follow at times. Lots of helpful cairns along the way, can get a bit confusing higher up where some split off to the right side of the rock scramble, as long as you hug the left wall you should be fine. 

Definitely better if you’re more seasoned as a hiker but lots of fun. 

We departed at 7:30am and it timed the sun rising over the ridge perfectly, really cool experience.

This was my first attempt to reach Higher Cathedral Rock.  I turned around 100ft from the summit as the sun had set and I didn't want to route find in the dark on exposure.

There's a fork in the trail and I chose the wrong path.  The correct way is to the left toward Higher Cathedral Spire, as this way does not require any bushwacking.  The other way approaches the face of Higher Cathedral Rock, but this is more for rock climbers and getting back to the gully requires a lot of fun bouldering, b
super steep and very difficult but it’s worth it.
Very slippy and steep terrain, be warned you have to be very careful going up and especially going back down, but the views are so beautiful!

Cathedral is a very hard hike. With that best marginal views at the top there are so many other better hikes in Yosemite Valley. My recommendation is only due this one after you’ve done everything else.

name: Merced Lake To Half Dome Loop Via John Muir Pack And Cloud Rest Trails
description:
This loop begins in Yosemite Valley, takes you through Little Yosemite Valley, to Merced Lake, and loops back around to summit both Clouds Rest and Half Dome. This loop features some of the most incredible scenery and views that Yosemite has to offer!

Half Dome is a serious endurance hike taking you 4,800 feet above the Yosemite Valley to spectacular views of Vernal and Nevada Falls, Liberty Cap, the Yosemite Valley, and the High Sierra. This is one of Yosemite National Park’s most iconic...

reviews.text: The valley is beautiful but it's very exposed and all of the trees burned down in the fire a few years ago. We got to the first swimming hole at Cascade Falls and that was totally worth it! Pack 2 L of water and 2 or 3 protein bars and electrolyte tabs. It can get very hot. We saw one juvenile rattle snake.

This was a much tougher trek than I had expected.  
Day 1: I started from Glacier Point and took the Panorama Trail to the JMT, rather than leave from Happy Isles.  (Glacier Point wilderness passes are easier to get and it saved 1000' of elevation gain, while adding a mile which is a fair trade-off.)  I camped at the LYV backpackers camp.  
Day 2: I headed towards Echo Valley, skipping Merced Lake.  I camped at an unnamed lake or pond along the trail a little west of Echo Valley which was beauti
reviews.date:
{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@id":"/trail/us/california/merced-lake-to-half-dome-loop-via-john-muir-pack-and-cloud-rest-trails","@type":"LocalBusiness","name":"Merced Lake, Half Dome, and Clouds Rest Loop via JMT","address":{"@type":"PostalAddress","addressLocality":"Yosemite Valley, California, United States"}},"reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","ratingValue":5},"reviewBody":"This was a much tougher trek than I had expected.  
Day 1: I started from Glacier Point and took the Panorama Trail to the JMT, rather than leave from Happy Isles.  (Glacier Point wilderness passes are easier to get and it saved 1000' of elevation gain, while adding a mile which is a fair trade-off.)  I camped at the LYV backpackers camp.  
Day 2: I headed towards Echo Valley, skipping Merced Lake.  I camped at an unnamed lake or pond along the trail a little west of Echo Valley which was beautiful and all mine for the evening.  
Day 3: I headed to Clouds Rest which was a bitch to ascend carrying a full pack.  Before the Clouds Rest trail was the Forsyth Trail which was buggy and had not been maintained judging by the dozens of downed trees.  The trail was also hard to find at times (special thanks to the AllTrails app lest I still be a-wandering.)  I camped at the intersection of the Clouds Rest trail and the JMT.
Day 4: I ditched my pack at the Half Dome trail head and made that epic trek to the top.  I returned to find that ravens had opened several of my backpack zippers and disbursed some of the contents.  Nothing ripped, broken, or missing.  They did the same to the other packs that were there.  From there I headed back to Happy Isles via JMT.  
While the mileage and elevation gain were not oppressive, I found two factors that made this 4-day trek more difficult:
1. The trails generally went up or down.  Very few flat stretches it seemed.
2. The trails were well-engineered with stone steps or had numerous stones embedded in the ground to reduce erosion and also serve as tripping hazards.  I had to watch carefully with every step (even using poles) and could not get into a good rhythm as a result.","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Erik Sander","url":"/members/erik-sander-1"}}

reviews.text:
An amazing trail. We did it as a 4 day/3 night trip. Day 1 took us to a spot along Merced River in Echo Valley, Day 2 took us to Lake Merced then up to Sunrise Creek, Day 3 took us across Clouds Rest, and Day 4 took us up Half Dome then finish the trail. Overall came to about 40 miles. Expect lots of ascent over the first three days.

The two of us brought 4 one liter bottles for water, and that barely was enough due to the heat. It was sitting in high 80s/low 90s and some portions became way ha

Two night, three day backpacking trip. Ended up being just over 40 miles. 

First night camp was just past the clouds rest junction- we hiked there, setup camp, then headed up half dome. Arrived at half dome around 5:00pm and had it to ourselves, absolutely beautiful. Two groups were heading up just as we came down. It was a warm day and we ended up drinking 2L each for the hike from camp and back. 

Day two was clouds rest and Merced lake. Clouds rest was stunning but I preferred the views (and

name: Dozier Dome Approach And Descent Trail
description:
This route is the rock climber's approach trail to Dozier Dome. This map also includes the descent trail from the top of the Dome. Your map and descent may vary from this map slightly depending on which route you climb up the Dome! Not all of the routes up Dozier reach the summit, and not all require a walk-off, so it's a good idea to check your guidebook for each climb. 

To approach Dozier, you'll park at a small trailhead past the approach to Medilicott but before you get to Tenaya Lake....

reviews.text: Short hike.  Involves some boulder scrambling and being careful as you are exposed to some potential for dangerous situations on the boulder domes
Yet another failed toulumne triple crown. BUT we were so much fast and got to cathedral. We just have work tomorrow so had to bail on it.
Trail has no signs, need GPS or map to find the way. Couldn‘t go to the top bc of snow but climbers were active up there. Good views of Lake Tenaya.
